Posts.Content: Hi I am the wife of a 56 yr. old man that is going to have robotics surgery on May 24th as time gets closer he is getting very quiet I am really worried about him I think he is worried if he made the right decision. I hope so too. He has never had surgery before, he has always been very healthy, so I am sure he is scared but doesn't want me to know or worry. Has anyone out there had their surgery at OSU in Columbus Ohio? If so I would love to hear from you. Cheryl
Posts.Title: Surgery getting closer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Tell your husband that, as long as his surgeon is highly experienced (at least 300 da Vinci's) & competent, he has nothing to worry about. Just contemplating surgery is a scary thought, especially to someone like me -- who considers having my teeth cleaned to be a major procedure. I had previously had only one surgery, but I was only 2-3 years old & do not remember it. Let your husband know that, from my experience, he is simply going to go to sleep & wake up later without cancer. He'll be sleepy the rest of the day & will hopefully get a good night's sleep before coming back home the next day. There really is very LITTLE, if any, pain from the surgery. The meds will see to that over the first couple days. After this, all I needed was Extra Strength Tylenol -- and I'm not even sure if I needed that -- just didn't want to take any chances. LOL If you can give us your husband's various stats, we can offer more comments -- such as his PSA readings over the past few years, his biopsy stats (Gleason scores, how many positive cores, staging, etc). Tell him to look forward to that day as the day he regains his health. Take care, Chuck His PSA was 9.58 he hadn't seen a Dr. in 4 years so I made him an appointment and won the battle of him going. His Dr. sent him to a urologist, biopsy was a gleason of 3+3=6, 7 out of 14 cores were positive for cancer. I have been his number one supporter and always will be. I think as time gets closer reality is kicking in. He has never had surgery and finally opened up to me the other night with the "what if's". He said he was even considering not to have the surgery. ED is what he is really concerned about. He is a very young 56 year old and NEVER sick. I wish they would have scheduled the surgery sooner because it gave him too much time to think. We were watching the news the other night and there was a women on there that had robotics and her bladder had been burned. Just what he needed to see right?
Posts.Title: Surgery getting closer

Posts.Title: Surgery getting closer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Sarg Since your husband is going to OSU hospital, who is his surgeon? If it is Dr. Vipul Patel, who was mine, he is an excellent surgeon as far as I am concerned. His main office is here in Celebration, FL but he also is an instructor and surgeon at OSU. By the way he had just went over 6,000 surgery's just prior to mine. My experience was nearly the same as Janei1's husband. Surgery was at 6 AM & I was up walking by noon. No pain meds needed either. Catheter was out 4 days after the surgery and around 7 to 8 weeks after the surgery I no longer needed Depends or pads. I wish your husband all the luck in the world. OSU is an excellent hospital and I'm sure all will go well. His Dr. is Shabsigh at OSU Cheryl

Posts.Title: Surgery getting closer

Posts.Content: Just wanted to thank all of you that have been helping me on this journey. I am so happy I found this website it has been a tremendous help to me and my husband. Even though he doesn't want to read anything or talk a lot about it just wants to get it over with, this forum has helped me to understand what he is going through. Especially thank you to Chuck, your knowledge and explanations are so helpful to others and your quick response is appreciated so much. I was so upset one day and I got on this forum and your explanation of things mad me cry with relief. I will be in touch as my husbands surgery is scheduled for next Friday, he is 56 years old and a gleason of 3+3. Fingers crossed, thank you all again. Cheryl
Posts.Title: Thank you

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH I did notice that I had kind of a burning/tingling sensation in my legs, especially the left one. Perhaps from nerves irritated during the surgery. They do put a patient into interesting, contorted positions during robotic surgery and having some discomfort in various parts of the body are pretty common. Did your husband have a da Vinci procedure? Chuck Yes he did have the da vinci. I just left a message for the Dr. Cheryl

Posts.Title: Leg pain

Posts.Content: Has anyone experienced leg pain after radical prosectomy? My husband is just 1week after surgery but having a lot of leg pain in just one leg on thigh. He did have lymph nodes removed don't know if its a nerve pain, goes back to Dr next week for path report. Cheryl
Posts.Title: Leg pain

Posts.Content: Has anyone experienced leg pain after radical prosectomy? My husband is just 1week after surgery but having a lot of leg pain in just one leg on thigh. He did have lymph nodes removed don't know if its a nerve pain, goes back to Dr next week for path report. Cheryl
Posts.Title: Leg pain

Posts.Content: Hi everyone My husband is now 3 weeks post surgery and doing well however part of his Ed healing is 1/2 viagra a day for 1 yr. Problem is insurance will only pay for 6 pills for 30 days. Pills are $32 each. Does anyone know of a better price or recommend any online ( safe) pharmacy's? I have seen it online in canada really cheap but not sure how safe. It really pisses me off that the insurance companies don't think this is important enough to cover it. Grrrrr! Cheryl
Posts.Title: Viagra

Posts.Content: Hi all, my husband surgery is this friday. I got on this prostate cancer forum for ladies only and started freaking out. The women were telling me my husband should not have surgery at a gleason 6 and telling me all of the horrible things that could happen and he should check into other treatments. Wow! I didn't expect that. Kind of got me thinking is my husband doing the right thing? Cheryl
Posts.Title: Information from Women only forum, what do you think?

Posts.Content: Hi all my husband finally got his pathology report today. His cancer was confined to his prostate, gleason stayed a 6, margins and lymph nodes all clear. Thank you god! I jumped out of my chair and hugged the Dr. This has been a long haul and i think we have aged 20 years in the last three months. This forum had been a god send to me, it was so educating and helpful beyond belief. Thank you all for your kind words and expertise. Keep helping others as you have helped us. Cheryl
Posts.Title: Pathology results

Posts.Content: Well its finally over my husband had his surgery on friday and is doing well. Cath is bothering him a bit but hopefully will come out friday. He has only taken 1pain pill. Surgery took 5 hours but the hospital gave me updates every 1 to 2 hrs. When he got to the hospital he was ready to back out (scared) but thankfully he went through with it. Now waiting on the path report which seems so long. Will keep you updated. Thank you everyone for your prayers and support. Cheryl Husband 56 Gleason 3+3 5 out of 14 cores positive for cancer
Posts.Title: Surgery update

Posts.Content: Hi everyone My husband just had his first PSA after prostate surgery 0.03. I am so surprised shouldn't it be undetectable? What could this mean? I am very concerned, the Dr. said at the postop visit that the cancer was confined to the prostate and no further treatment needed and margins were all clear. Thought this was all over but guess not. Cheryl
Posts.Title: First psa after prostectomy

Posts.Content: My husbands surgery is tomorrow morning what should i take for him to wear home with the cath? Does it attach to your leg? Boxers? Whats best?
Posts.Title: What to take to the hospital
